description: The Category 2 storm approached the North Carolina coast on Thursday, with winds of up to 110 miles an hour.
title: Maps: Hurricane Florence’s Approach Toward the Carolinas
title_page: Maps: Hurricane Florence’s Approach Toward the Carolinas - The New York Times
text:
View the latest maps tracking Hurricane Florence’s path, damage and impact. This page is no longer updated.
Hurricane Florence approached the North Carolina coast on Thursday as a Category 2 storm, with winds of up to 110 miles an hour, as forecasters said that it had the potential for catastrophic, life-threatening damage and rainfall.

When the Storm Will Hit the Hardest
The strongest winds were expected to reach Wilmington, N.C., which sits in the storm’s path, early on Friday morning. Enter your city below to see when the worst winds are forecast to hit.

Mandatory Evacuations in Three States
By Thursday morning, mandatory evacuations had been ordered along coastal counties in Virginia, North Carolina, and South Carolina, with high winds, severe flooding and widespread power outages expected. The map below includes partial county evacuations.

Heavy Rain Forecast in the Carolinas
As of Thursday morning, the storm was expected to bring more than a foot of rainfall in parts of North Carolina and South Carolina over the next five days.

Storm Surge Expected Along the Coast
Up and down the coast of the Carolinas, waters were expected to rise anywhere from 4 to 8 feet. A storm surge of more than 12 feet was predicted near Greenville and Jacksonville, North Carolina, as of Thursday evening.

Past Hurricanes in the Region
At least three storms have hit the region with hurricane-force winds since 2008. The largest, Hurricane Irene in 2011, had hurricane-force winds that spanned up to 135 miles when it hit the coast of North Carolina. Hurricane Florence, which is expected to make landfall on Friday, has already reached that size.
